resolution.description: A fix for this issue is checked into the tree and tested.
resolution.name: Fixed

status.description: A resolution has been taken, and it is awaiting verification by reporter. From here issues are either reopened, or are closed.
status.name: Resolved

worklogs.comment:
wjones127 opened a new pull request, #14008:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14008

   Adds a little more explanation of the difference between tables and record batches, as well as a diagram representation.

github-actions[bot] commented on PR #14008:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14008#issuecomment-1232133972

   https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/ARROW-13454

github-actions[bot] commented on PR #14008:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14008#issuecomment-1232133996

   :warning: Ticket **has not been started in JIRA**, please click 'Start Progress'.

lidavidm commented on code in PR #14008:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14008#discussion_r958911296


##########
docs/source/cpp/tables.rst:
##########
@@ -77,6 +77,17 @@ has a schema which must match its arrays' datatypes.
 Record batches are a convenient unit of work for various serialization
 and computation functions, possibly incremental.
 
+.. image:: tables-versus-record-batches.svg
+   :alt: A graphical representation of an Arrow Table and a Record Batch, with
+         structure as described in text above.
+
+Because record batches can be represented as a struct array, they can be 
+exported through the C data interface between implementations. Tables and 

Review Comment:
   Do we want to assume knowledge of the C Data Interface?
   
   We could make this more generic: "they can be sent between implementations, such as via IPC (link), or via the C Data Interface (link)"

wjones127 commented on code in PR #14008:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14008#discussion_r958925250


##########
docs/source/cpp/tables.rst:
##########
@@ -77,6 +77,17 @@ has a schema which must match its arrays' datatypes.
 Record batches are a convenient unit of work for various serialization
 and computation functions, possibly incremental.
 
+.. image:: tables-versus-record-batches.svg

+
+Because record batches can be represented as a struct array, they can be 
+exported through the C data interface between implementations. Tables and 
+chunked arrays, on the other hand, are concepts in the C++ implementation, not 

Review Comment:
   Yeah maybe it should be C++ and it's bindings (Python is one of those).
   
   Another diagram I'd like to have is which implementations are base ones (e.g. C++, Rust), and which are bindings (and to whom). I know where C++/Python/R/Ruby, C#, and Rust sit. I'm still unclear where Go and Java are though.

+.. image:: tables-versus-record-batches.svg
+   :alt: A graphical representation of an Arrow Table and a Record Batch, with

+
+Because record batches can be represented as a struct array, they can be 
+exported through the C data interface between implementations. Tables and 
+chunked arrays, on the other hand, are concepts in the C++ implementation, not 

Review Comment:
   Go and Java are standalone implementations like C++/C♯/Rust/Julia (Java was one of the original implementations)

drin commented on code in PR #14008:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14008#discussion_r958951760


##########
docs/source/cpp/tables.rst:
##########
@@ -77,6 +77,17 @@ has a schema which must match its arrays' datatypes.
 Record batches are a convenient unit of work for various serialization
 and computation functions, possibly incremental.
 
+.. image:: tables-versus-record-batches.svg
+   :alt: A graphical representation of an Arrow Table and a Record Batch, with
+         structure as described in text above.
+
+Because record batches can be represented as a struct array, they can be 
+exported through the C data interface between implementations. Tables and 
+chunked arrays, on the other hand, are concepts in the C++ implementation, not 
+in the Arrow format itself, so they aren't directly portable.
+
+However, a table can be converted to and built from a sequence of record 
+batches easily without needing to copy the underlying array buffers.

Review Comment:
   If the columns have different chunking, wouldn't it be necessary to normalize when converting to a RecordBatch?
   
   That being said, a Table is basically a structural view of a RecordBatch: each RecordBatch Array can be wrapped in a ChunkedArray trivially because the buffers are separate and a ChunkedArray is *mostly* an ArrayVector (though, I assume not entirely).

drin commented on PR #14008:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14008#issuecomment-1232198649

   Not sure if it's a significant thing, but a Table can easily modify schema metadata whereas a recordbatch cannot (I'm also not sure if there's a reason RecordBatch doesn't have `ReplaceSchemaMetadata`).

wjones127 commented on code in PR #14008:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14008#discussion_r958956177


##########
docs/source/cpp/tables.rst:
##########
@@ -77,6 +77,17 @@ has a schema which must match its arrays' datatypes.
 Record batches are a convenient unit of work for various serialization
 and computation functions, possibly incremental.
 
+.. image:: tables-versus-record-batches.svg
+   :alt: A graphical representation of an Arrow Table and a Record Batch, with
+         structure as described in text above.
+
+Because record batches can be represented as a struct array, they can be 
+exported through the C data interface between implementations. Tables and 
+chunked arrays, on the other hand, are concepts in the C++ implementation, not 
+in the Arrow format itself, so they aren't directly portable.
+
+However, a table can be converted to and built from a sequence of record 
+batches easily without needing to copy the underlying array buffers.

Review Comment:
   > If the columns have different chunking, wouldn't it be necessary to normalize when converting to a RecordBatch?
   
   `TableBatchReader` will create a RB boundary any place there is a chunk boundary. So if you have lots of different chunking you will get lots of uneven batches. I imagine there's some function to re-chunk more reasonably if needed.

westonpace commented on PR #14008:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14008#issuecomment-1232318340

   > Not sure if it's a significant thing, but a Table can easily modify schema metadata whereas a recordbatch cannot (I'm also not sure if there's a reason RecordBatch doesn't have ReplaceSchemaMetadata).
   
   I think that is just a gap in utility APIs.  `ReplaceSchemaMetadata` isn't really modifying the table.  It's creating a brand new table with the new metadata.  You should be able to do the same thing with record batches.

pitrou commented on code in PR #14008:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14008#discussion_r959287295


##########
docs/source/cpp/tables.rst:
##########
@@ -77,6 +77,17 @@ has a schema which must match its arrays' datatypes.
 Record batches are a convenient unit of work for various serialization
 and computation functions, possibly incremental.
 
+.. image:: tables-versus-record-batches.svg
+   :alt: A graphical representation of an Arrow Table and a Record Batch, with
+         structure as described in text above.
+
+Because record batches can be represented as a struct array, they can be 
+exported through the C data interface between implementations. Tables and 
+chunked arrays, on the other hand, are concepts in the C++ implementation, not 
+in the Arrow format itself, so they aren't directly portable.
+
+However, a table can be converted to and built from a sequence of record 
+batches easily without needing to copy the underlying array buffers.

Review Comment:
   We don't have any function to re-chunk more reasonably, no. I think heterogeneous chunkings should be uncommon in general, anyway, since all data sources should yield homogenous chunkings (i.e. a stream of RecordBatch).

pitrou commented on code in PR #14008:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14008#discussion_r959288158


##########

+.. image:: tables-versus-record-batches.svg
+   :alt: A graphical representation of an Arrow Table and a Record Batch, with
+         structure as described in text above.
+
+Because record batches can be represented as a struct array, they can be 
+exported through the C data interface between implementations. Tables and 

Review Comment:
   Also I wouldn't go too much into details here, and remove the mention about "can be represented as a struct array".

ksuarez1423 commented on code in PR #14008:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14008#discussion_r959841323


##########
docs/source/cpp/tables.rst:
##########
@@ -77,6 +77,18 @@ has a schema which must match its arrays' datatypes.
 Record batches are a convenient unit of work for various serialization
 and computation functions, possibly incremental.
 
+.. image:: tables-versus-record-batches.svg
+   :alt: A graphical representation of an Arrow Table and a Record Batch, with
+         structure as described in text above.
+
+Record batches can be sent between implementations, such as via 
+:ref:`IPC <format-ipc>` or
+via the :doc:`C Data Interface <../format/CDataInterface>`. Tables and 
+chunked arrays, on the other hand, are concepts in the C++ implementation (and
+its bindings), not in the Arrow format itself, so they aren't directly portable.

Review Comment:
   Can we link up to the list of bindings somewhere, or should we expect readers to know if they're using a binded or fully-implemented implementation?



##########
docs/source/cpp/tables.rst:
##########
@@ -77,6 +77,17 @@ has a schema which must match its arrays' datatypes.
 Record batches are a convenient unit of work for various serialization
 and computation functions, possibly incremental.
 
+.. image:: tables-versus-record-batches.svg
+   :alt: A graphical representation of an Arrow Table and a Record Batch, with
+         structure as described in text above.
+
+Because record batches can be represented as a struct array, they can be 
+exported through the C data interface between implementations. Tables and 
+chunked arrays, on the other hand, are concepts in the C++ implementation, not 
+in the Arrow format itself, so they aren't directly portable.
+
+However, a table can be converted to and built from a sequence of record 
+batches easily without needing to copy the underlying array buffers.

Review Comment:
   What exactly happens, if you break at every boundary? Does each RecordBatch just store pointers to start and end, and the breaking each boundary ensures contiguity?

wjones127 commented on code in PR #14008:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14008#discussion_r959860181


##########
docs/source/cpp/tables.rst:
##########
@@ -77,6 +77,17 @@ has a schema which must match its arrays' datatypes.
 Record batches are a convenient unit of work for various serialization
 and computation functions, possibly incremental.
 
+.. image:: tables-versus-record-batches.svg
+   :alt: A graphical representation of an Arrow Table and a Record Batch, with
+         structure as described in text above.
+
+Because record batches can be represented as a struct array, they can be 
+exported through the C data interface between implementations. Tables and 
+chunked arrays, on the other hand, are concepts in the C++ implementation, not 
+in the Arrow format itself, so they aren't directly portable.
+
+However, a table can be converted to and built from a sequence of record 
+batches easily without needing to copy the underlying array buffers.

Review Comment:
   > Does each RecordBatch just store pointers to start and end, and the breaking each boundary ensures contiguity?
   
   Arrays generally have a `shared_ptr<Buffer>`, an offset, and a length. You can `Slice()` any array, and it just copies the shared pointer to the buffer, and adjusts the offset and length accordingly.

wjones127 commented on code in PR #14008:
URL: https://github.com/apache/arrow/pull/14008#discussion_r959862298


##########
docs/source/cpp/tables.rst:
##########
@@ -77,6 +77,18 @@ has a schema which must match its arrays' datatypes.
 Record batches are a convenient unit of work for various serialization
 and computation functions, possibly incremental.
 
+.. image:: tables-versus-record-batches.svg
+   :alt: A graphical representation of an Arrow Table and a Record Batch, with
+         structure as described in text above.
+
+Record batches can be sent between implementations, such as via 
+:ref:`IPC <format-ipc>` or
+via the :doc:`C Data Interface <../format/CDataInterface>`. Tables and 
+chunked arrays, on the other hand, are concepts in the C++ implementation (and
+its bindings), not in the Arrow format itself, so they aren't directly portable.

Review Comment:
   This is within the C++ user guide, so I'm not too worried about Python or R users reading this and not being sure if this applies to them. Presumably they would only be on this page if they already knew!
   
   But we should create a diagram on the Docs homepage that shows the relationship between implementations. I'll leave that as a separate ticket though.

Review Comment:
   Let's perhaps remove the mention of bindings then?

pitrou commented on code in PR #14008:

        Not part of the columnar format; this term is specific to

-       its bindings).
+       its bindings and Go).

Review Comment:

Review Comment:
   Let's be less specific perhaps, and say "for example C++ and its bindings"?

issuetype.description: An improvement or enhancement to an existing feature or task.
issuetype.name: Improvement

fields.description:
It is not clear what the difference is between Tables and Record Batches is as described on [https://arrow.apache.org/docs/cpp/tables.html#tables]

_A [{{arrow::Table}}|https://arrow.apache.org/docs/cpp/api/table.html#_CPPv4N5arrow5TableE] is a two-dimensional dataset with chunked arrays for columns_

_A [{{arrow::RecordBatch}}|https://arrow.apache.org/docs/cpp/api/table.html#_CPPv4N5arrow11RecordBatchE] is a two-dimensional dataset of a number of contiguous arrays_

Or maybe the distinction between _chunked arrays_ and _contiguous arrays_ can be clarified.

comments.body: Is this still desired/not implemented? I'd be happy to go see what I can do.

Yes. One important thing to note to new users as well: The chunk lengths of arrays in a table do not necessarily have to align, though they frequently will if the table was created from a sequence of Record Batches.

Okay, one last thing, before I make any incorrect promises in documentation – the record batches are not themselves guaranteeing contiguity _between_ arrays, correct? Just that the arrays are internally contiguous?

{quote}the record batches are not themselves guaranteeing contiguity between arrays, correct? Just that the arrays are internally contiguous?{quote}

Correct. Record batches don't even have exclude ownership over the arrays they contain; a single array might be referenced by multiple record batches.
